page.title: 04TRANSPORT
page.content: Living in the country today is totally different from even forty years ago. Until then, cars on the road were not many, scince few could afford to buy one; and the railway system was widespread, covering most small towns and even remote villages, with stations about 15 -20 miles apart, making travel possible, and cheap, ifat times slow. Now there are few rural railway stations. The coming of the mass-produced motor-car has brought with it many miles of motorway, linked by lesser roads, taking over from travel by canal or coastal shipping, and even by rail. Domestic airways compete with motorways between major cities. All have a great bearing on country living today both from the point of view easy access and increased noise.
